item.title: Watching Tiger Woods Play an Often-Hidden Role: Dad
item.media:description: Tiger Woods, right, and his son, Charlie, will play in a televised father-son event this weekend.
item.description: Watching Woods and his son, Charlie, on the golf course offers a rare window into a side of Woods fans never see: dad.
item.dc:creator: Karen Crouse

item.title: Its Football Season Over, Cal Wonders: Was It Worth It?
item.media:description: Cal’s final game, at Washington State, was called before the players took the field.
item.description: Some top programs will play a dozen games this season. The Golden Bears managed only four before their season ended with a text message.
item.dc:creator: John Branch

item.title: For Opponents of Native American Nicknames, 2020 Has Brought Hope
item.media:description: After abandoning its nickname and Native American logo in July, the N.F.L. franchise in Washington chose a simple temporary replacement, the Washington Football Team.
item.description: Leaders in the movement to rid sports of such nicknames and the logos that accompany them saw a domino effect building in public schools after two major professional teams made changes. But there are staunch holdouts.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein

item.title: NFL Week 15 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
item.media:description: Drew Brees hasn’t played since Week 10. Can he come back from a rib injury to lead New Orleans in a crucial matchup against Kansas City?
item.description: Saturday games return, but this week is dominated by a potential Super Bowl preview between the Saints and the Chiefs.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Hoffman

item.title: A First for Sarah Fuller, but That Wasn’t the Last of It
item.media:description: Sarah Fuller gained more notice by kicking for Vanderbilt’s winless football team than by leading Vanderbilt’s women’s soccer team to the Southeastern Conference tournament title.
item.description: Women broke through glass ceilings to gain roles in men’s sports this year. But the celebration of their place in history, and sometimes the pushback, can overshadow their work.
item.dc:creator: Marisa Ingemi

item.title: College Football Season Is Nearly Over. Then the Big TV Negotiations Begin.
item.media:credit: Matt Cashore/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: ESPN’s pregame show “College GameDay” is a fixture of the college football season for a company that pays hundreds of millions of dollars to the Big Ten Conference to show its games. Canceled games present a new financial challenge to those deals.
item.description: ESPN and Fox didn’t get about 20 games from the Big Ten Conference this season. Those events were worth roughly $110 million, leaving college sports and TV executives with much to resolve.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper and Alan Blinder

item.title: What Qualifies as Success at Borussia Dortmund?
item.media:description: Three of Dortmund’s crown jewels: Giovanni Reyna, Erling Haaland and Jadon Sancho.
item.description: Borussia Dortmund’s business is winning matches and grooming some of the world’s best young talent. To do both, sometimes you have to put up with a few growing pains.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Baseball Rights a Wrong by Adding Negro Leagues to Official Records
item.media:description: From left to right, the pitchers John Stanley, Frank McAllister and Gene Smith of the Negro National League's New York Black Yankees standing on the top step of their dugout in 1942.
item.description: More than 3,400 players from seven leagues that operated from 1920 to 1948 will now be considered major leaguers in a move that will shake up the record books.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner

item.title: Manny Ramirez, 48, Brings His Bat to the Sydney Blue Sox
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Manny Ramirez seen at Sydney Blue Sox stadium before team practice last week.
item.description: The Sydney Blue Sox were stunned that Manny Ramirez, 48, wanted to join the Australian Baseball League. They’re counting on the former superstar to raise baseball’s profile in the country.
item.dc:creator: Gary Phillips

item.title: CAS Reduces Russia’s Doping Ban to Two Years
item.media:description: The decision to reduce Russia’s ban from global sports includes important loopholes for Russian athletes.
item.description: The ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport reduced a four-year ban to two. It will keep Russian teams — but not necessarily Russian athletes — out of the next two Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja

item.title: Australian Open Is Postponed Because of the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.media:description: Dominic Thiem, left, and Novak Djokovic in the 2020 Australian Open men’s final.
item.description: With infections surging in other parts of the world, the first Grand Slam tennis event of 2021 has been delayed by three weeks, according to a schedule released by the men’s tour.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman

item.title: How Putting on a Mask Raised Naomi Osaka’s Voice
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Naomi Osaka after winning the U.S. Open.
item.description: She used her time away from competing during the pandemic to reflect on the world and her place within it. When the time came to speak, she approached it in her own distinct way.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron

item.title: Can Any A.F.C. Team Catch the Chiefs?
item.media:description: Kansas City quarterback Patrick Mahomes, left, and receiver Tyreek Hill, with football, usually connect for a few 40-yard touchdowns to compensate for any Chiefs miscues.
item.description: Sure, Kansas City (12-1) is flawed, but its closest challengers have a long way to go to usurp a Super Bowl berth.
item.dc:creator: Mike Tanier

item.title: N.B.A. Hopes for ‘as Close to a Normal Season as Possible’
item.media:description: The N.B.A. is back, but it’s clear it’s not the same — and no one can be sure when it will be closer to what it was before the pandemic.
item.description: The league is embarking on a season with restrictions but no bubble: Yes to trips to Whole Foods. No to crowded elevators and the hotel gift shop.
item.dc:creator: Marc Stein

item.title: Not the Matchup They Wanted: Gennadiy Golovkin vs. Kamil Szeremeta and Saul Alvarez vs. Callum Smith
item.media:description: Saul Alvarez, who is known as Canelo, celebrates after defeating Sergey Kovalev by knockout in a light heavyweight WBO title bout, in Las Vegas in 2019.
item.description: The two stars face other contenders as the DAZN streaming service works through complicated factors to arrange for another rematch.
item.dc:creator: Morgan Campbell

item.title: Henrik Lundqvist Will Not Play Next Season Due to a Heart Condition
item.media:description: Henrik Lundqvist last played in August, at the N.H.L.’s bubble in Toronto.
item.description: Two months after signing with the Washington Capitals, the former Rangers goaltender said he made the decision after “many weeks of tests and conversations with specialists around the country.”
item.dc:creator: Allan Kreda

item.title: Cory Booker's College Athletes Bill of Rights Would Let Players Share Profits
item.media:credit: Ken Ruinard/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Trevor Lawrence has had a terrific career at Clemson. Legislation introduced by Senator Cory Booker would lead to players like Lawrence receiving a share of the profits generated by their sport.
item.description: The legislation, introduced by Senator Cory Booker, could allow college football players and men’s basketball players to receive six-figure paychecks.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz

item.title: Video Games in 2020: These People Are Changing the Culture
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benita Novshadian, a professional Counter-Strike player, at her home gaming station. “The esports scene for women right now is the biggest it has ever been,” she said.
item.description: Designers, competitors, streamers, voice actors and labor activists have been working to make gaming more inclusive.
item.category: The Last of Us Part II (Video Game)
item.dc:creator: Anita Sarkeesian and Carolyn Petit

item.title: Roberto Firmino's Goal Vaults Liverpool Over Tottenham in Premier League
item.media:description: Roberto Firmino’s header in the 90th minute gave Liverpool a 2-1 victory over Tottenham at Anfield.
item.description: A lineup altered by injury, and supplemented by youth, summons the energy to beat Tottenham at Anfield.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Yankees Say D.J. LeMahieu Is Worth Waiting For
item.media:credit: Gary A. Vasquez/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: D.J. LeMahieu hit .364 for the Yankees in this year’s truncated 60-game season.
item.description: The team’s primary off-season goal remains re-signing the free-agent infielder, who could command a lucrative four-year contract at age 32.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner

item.title: Jazz Sign Yogi Ferrell and Malcolm Miller
item.description: The Utah Jazz announced today that the team has signed guard Yogi Ferrell and forward Malcolm Miller.
item.dc:creator: Angie Treasure

item.title: Sale of Utah Jazz to Ryan and Ashley Smith approved by NBA Board of Governors
item.description: The Utah Jazz today announced that tech entrepreneur and Qualtrics founder, Ryan Smith, and his wife Ashley, are the new majority owners
item.dc:creator: Angie Treasure

item.title: Threes? Please. Utah Jazz catch fire from long range and beat the L.A. Clippers in their preseason finale
item.description: Three is the magic number. Yes, it is.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Falk

item.title: Utah Jazz sign Tre Scott
item.description: The Utah Jazz announced today that the team has signed forward Tre Scott. Per team policy, terms of the deal were not released.
item.dc:creator: Angie Treasure

item.title: Jazz waive Nigel Williams-Goss
item.description: The Utah Jazz announced today that the team has waived guard Nigel Williams-Goss.
item.dc:creator: Angie Treasure

item.title: Defense and a third-quarter run propel the Utah Jazz past the Phoenix Suns in preseason play
item.description: Things weren’t clicking for Donovan Mitchell and the Utah Jazz early in Monday night’s preseason tune-up.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Falk

item.title: The Utah Jazz start preseason play with a win over the Suns in their first game back at Vivint Arena since March
item.description: Vivint Arena looked different. Of course it did. It had to.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Falk

item.title: Utah Jazz sign Trevon Bluiett
item.description: The Utah Jazz announced today that the team has signed guard Trevon Bluiett. Per team policy, terms of the deal were not released.
item.dc:creator: Angie Treasure

item.title: Shaquille Harrison brings toughness and a defensive mindset to the Utah Jazz
item.description: Shaquille Harrison didn’t need to make a good first impression with his new teammate.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Falk

item.title: Roundball Roundup: Kyle Goon remembering Donovan Mitchell’s rookie season
item.description: Check any NBA preview. The Los Angeles Lakers are at the top, then everyone else.
item.dc:creator: JP Chunga
